awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research - Digging deeper: Do deeper roots enhance deeper water and carbon fluxes and alter the trajectory of chemical weathering in woody-encroached grasslands?
awd_abstract_narration:
Within grasslands, woody plants are increasing in cover and abundance.  The replacement of grasslands by woody plants can change the way water, nutrients, and metals are stored and move through soil. This project studies these changes in grasslands in Kansas. The project links the fields of water science, rock chemistry and soil chemistry. The project connects the way water moves and is stored in the ground to how soil and rock chemically breaks down. Investigating how roots of woody plants altered water flow in the ground is important to understanding how Earth will respond to future changes in climate. This research provides training across different fields of science including geology, biology, and chemistry. Educational materials will be developed for all grade levels including K-12 and college. 

The goal of this research is to understand how roots respond to changes in climate and land use, and how roots control the movement of water and nutrients through landscapes. Specifically, this research studies how deeper roots associated with woody plant encroachment enhances transport of water and carbon to greater depths, increases the water residence time in the subsurface, and enhances the potential for weathering at depth. To accomplish this goal, integrated field and modeling approaches will be conducted at the watershed scale. Data will be collected at the Konza Prairie (KS, USA), where long-term burning experiments have resulted in the encroachment of woody vegetation. This research relies on: 1) long-term measures of vegetation cover, stream discharge, water isotopes, and water solute chemistry, and 2) new measurements of the subsurface including root density and distribution, soil structure, soil water potential, soil gas concentrations, and solute chemistry. Collectively, this research links water residence time to fluxes of nutrients. The project partners with the Konza Environmental Education Program to provide educational materials and training on woody plant encroachment into prairies. An online modular toolbox for water quality and quantity is developed for undergraduate and graduate students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The primary goals of this project were to address two major knowledge gaps (intellectual merits): 1) To investigate how changes in root system architecture due to climatic and human activities affect soil macropore distribution and subsurface water partitioning, resulting in altered catchment storage age and transit time distribution; 2) To evaluate the influence of these shifts in hydrologic processes on biogeochemical fluxes by primarily affecting transport rates and secondarily influencing chemical transformations. The project also aimed to promote NSF's mission of diversity in STEM fields (broader impacts).

Intellectual merits:

The team collected comprehensive data and analyzed soil, water, and root data from different catchments experiencing varying degrees of woody encroachment. The team also developed conceptual and numerical models to understand the impact of woody plants' root systems on soil structure, ecohydrologic fluxes, and solute generation. Findings from this project have shed light on how woody encroachment alters soi and root structure, and how structure change influence hydrological and biogeochemical functioning. In particular, we found that despite an increase in precipitation, declining streamflow was highly correlated with rapid increases in shrub cover and evapotranspiration. The groundwater is becoming more isotopically depleted while the surface water is become more enriched, and that dogwood are hungry for water not matter what. Decreased streamflow deepened subsurface flow paths, leading to higher proportion of deeper groundwater over time. This trend of deeper flow path coincides with increasing concentration of dissolved inorganic carbon, suggesting that water balance and hydrological changes can influence not only carbonate weathering, but also water quality alteration and possible CO2 evasion from streams and rivers.

Despite progresses, many puzzles and questions remain. 1) There is little difference in groundwater residence times from the wells in N1B compared to N4D but a difference in the soil water residence leads to more aggressive or less CO2 charged water recharging the woodier sites. 2) storage is pretty limited in the system and operates as fill and spill. 3)  it is likely that there are more and deeper preferential flow under the woodier sites.

Broader Impacts:

The research results shed lights on changing streamflow and stream water quality in woody-encroached Konza LTER, and possibly broadly Great Plains. The research trained two female PhD students and one female Master student and involved one female postdoc researcher. The project fostered convergent thinking by exploring long-term records of stream water, groundwater, and precipitation isotopic data to examine how rainfall patterns propagate through the subsurface and how our work contributes to understanding carbon budgets in grassland systems.

In addition, our team hosted two hydrology field camps at Konza Prairie. The camps trained 11 undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds to critically think about how woody encroachment affects critical zone processes. This promotes NSF's mission of diversity in STEM fields by supporting the training of three female graduate students, two of whom identify as people of color, and one as gay/lesbian. Our field camp also saw a significant representation of female and non-binary individuals and first-generation college students.
